G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in this Court pursuant to **G.L. c. 218, § 19** and **G.L. c. 223, §§ 2 and 8**, because the premises and events giving rise to this claim occurred in Cambridge, Middlesex County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 2 and 8.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in this Court pursuant to **G.L. c. 218, § 19** and **G.L. c. 223, §§ 2 and 8**, because the premises and events giving rise to this claim occurred in Cambridge, Middlesex County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under **G.L. c. 186, § 14**, a landlord shall not “directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment” of a tenant and shall be liable for actual and consequential damages resulting from such interference.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6C.proposition: Award reasonable court costs and statutory interest as provided by **G.L. c. 231, § 6C**;

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in all residential tenancies in Massachusetts and protects tenants from serious and unreasonable interferences materially affecting their tenancy.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly treats the covenant of quiet enjoyment as an implied term in the tenants’ leases and analyzes its breach based on “very substantially” depriving tenants of quiet enjoyment by loud, late-night bar noise. The court frames violation in terms of serious, substantial interference with the habitability and beneficial enjoyment of the premises, matching the proposition that the implied covenant protects tenants from serious and unreasonable interferences materially affecting their tenancy.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that the tenants were ‘very substantially deprived’ of quiet enjoyment of their leased premises ‘for a substantial time’… He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did… they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

O\u2019Brien v. Hurley, 325 Mass. 285, 2.proposition: Defendant’s actions and omissions constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under both statutory and common law.
O\u2019Brien v. Hurley, 325 Mass. 285, 2.case_name: Department of Public Utilities v. New England Telephone & Telegraph Co.
O\u2019Brien v. Hurley, 325 Mass. 285, 2.support_reasoning: The opinion is a public utility rate-regulation case involving the Department of Public Utilities and a telephone company; it concerns statutory authority over rate schedules, suspensions, and court stays. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, covenants of quiet enjoyment, or any discussion of statutory or common-law quiet enjoyment. Therefore it cannot serve as authority that a defendant’s actions or omissions constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under either statutory or common law.
O\u2019Brien v. Hurley, 325 Mass. 285, 2.relevant_excerpt: “In our opinion the rights of the parties, succinctly stated, were and are as follows: If it were not for the department’s statutory power to regulate rates the company would have had the full right to promulgate and put into effect the $15,000,000 rates filed April 21, 1948. … The order was also subject under § 5 and the rules of this court to having its enforcement ‘stayed’ until its lawfulness or unlawfulness could be determined after full hearing in this court.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Defendant, by directing and permitting extensive construction activities adjacent to Plaintiff’s unit and failing to take reasonable steps to prevent or mitigate excessive noise, dust, and disruption, has “directly or indirectly interfered” with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The case does interpret and apply G.L. c. 186, § 14’s “directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment” language, but only in the context of a landlord’s failure to provide heat, not construction-related noise, dust, or disruption. It stands for the broader principle that a serious impairment of the premises (here, lack of heat) can breach quiet enjoyment regardless of intent, but it does not involve or discuss construction activities or analogous disturbances. Using it specifically to support a proposition about construction interference is therefore an extrapolation rather than direct authority.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season… seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’… and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’ … liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: The severity and duration of the interference were unreasonable in the circumstances, especially in light of Plaintiff’s residential working needs and Defendant’s inadequate ameliorative measures.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court held that if tenants are unable to use common areas because of criminal activity and the landlord has taken no or inadequate measures to remove offending nontenants, that situation can constitute a serious (i.e., substantial and unreasonable) interference with quiet enjoyment. The opinion expressly ties liability to both the severity/duration of the interference with residential use and the landlord’s inadequate ameliorative actions, aligning with the proposition’s emphasis on unreasonable interference in light of residential needs and insufficient remedial measures.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development… then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises… We do believe, however, that if the defendant has failed to take any measures… to remove unwelcome persons… and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.… If the defendant has taken no action or inadequate action… then the plaintiffs will be entitled to judgment….”

Anderson v. Gabriel, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 4.raw_text: Anderson v. Gabriel, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 436, 440 (1998)
Anderson v. Gabriel, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 4.proposition: Plaintiff’s right to quiet enjoyment includes freedom from unreasonable disturbance, excessive noise, and intrusions by dust or contaminants materially affecting the habitability of the dwelling.
Anderson v. Gabriel, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 4.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns allocation of eminent domain proceeds, finality of judgments, Rule 60(b) jurisdiction, and a reach-and-apply action by a judgment creditor. It does not address landlord-tenant rights, quiet enjoyment, or issues of disturbance, noise, dust, or contaminants affecting habitability. The cited case therefore does not provide authority for the stated proposition about a plaintiff’s right to quiet enjoyment and habitability conditions.
Anderson v. Gabriel, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 4.relevant_excerpt: “An action to reach and apply is essentially a two-step process. ‘The first is the establishment of an indebtedness on the part of the principal defendant to the plaintiff. The second is the process for collecting the debt, when established, out of property rights which cannot be reached on an execution.’ Stockbridge v. Mixer, 215 Mass. 415, 418 (1913). Bressler v. Averbuck, 322 Mass. 139, 141 (1947).”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Plaintiff’s right to quiet enjoyment includes freedom from unreasonable disturbance, excessive noise, and intrusions by dust or contaminants materially affecting the habitability of the dwelling.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This concurring/dissenting opinion section of Hemingway concerns the implied warranty of habitability and the interaction of sanitary/building codes with landlord–tenant rent obligations. It does not discuss the covenant of quiet enjoyment or define it in terms of freedom from unreasonable disturbance, noise, dust, or contaminants. The cited page range and text are about legal standards for habitability and enforcement mechanisms, not about quiet enjoyment or interference from noise or dust, so it does not support the specific proposition stated.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: "Since 1960 dwelling units have been subject to the State Sanitary Code... The Code, which has the force of law and applies throughout the Commonwealth, fixes minimum standards of fitness of structures for human habitation. It does so in great detail and to an extent never before incorporated in any statute. It expressly provides that '[n]o person shall ... let to another for occupancy any dwelling... which does not comply' with its provisions, and further provides a criminal penalty for violation of its provisions."

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 101 (198.proposition: The fact that the construction occurred during standard working hours does not preclude a finding of breach where, as here, the result was a consistent and substantial impairment of use of the premises.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 101 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns flooding, habitability, quiet enjoyment, and emotional distress; it does not involve construction activity or any discussion of whether work done during standard business hours can nevertheless constitute a breach due to substantial impairment of use. Nothing in the reasoning or holding addresses time-of-day limits or construction-related interference. Therefore, this case does not provide authority for the specific proposition about construction during standard working hours.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 101 (198.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929)… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … [M]ore recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights.”

Winchester Constr. Co. v. Miller, 117 Ma.raw_text: Winchester Constr. Co. v. Miller, 117 Mass. 283, 285 (1875)
Winchester Constr. Co. v. Miller, 117 Ma.proposition: The modest rent abatement offered by Defendant does not cure the violation, as the harm to Plaintiff’s comfort and use continued unabated.
Winchester Constr. Co. v. Miller, 117 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with Massachusetts procedure concerning writs of review, the rights of bail to surrender their principal after a writ of review is entered, and the timing of exceptions. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, rent abatements, or harms to a tenant’s comfort and use. Accordingly, it provides no authority for the proposition that a modest rent abatement does not cure a continuing violation affecting a tenant’s comfort and use.
Winchester Constr. Co. v. Miller, 117 Ma.relevant_excerpt: "A review, under our statutes, is equivalent to a new trial after judgment. Everything is open upon the review which might have been suggested in the original action. ... The original judgment is not indeed set aside, but stands until the judgment in the review, which may affirm, reverse or modify the former judgment, in whole or in part, or make such other disposition of the case as may be necessary to secure the just and legal rights of all parties."

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 200 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Defendant’s conduct also constitutes an “indirect interference” under **G.L. c. 186, § 14**, notwithstanding the fact that the renovation served a legitimate purpose.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The case is about common‑law warranty of habitability and rent abatement; it does not involve G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor does it discuss “indirect interference” with quiet enjoyment or tenant rights under that statute. The holding is that a landlord is strictly liable for rent abatement once on notice of habitability defects, regardless of fault or good‑faith repair efforts, but that is conceptually different from finding a statutory violation under c. 186, § 14, especially in the context of legitimate renovations. Thus this opinion cannot be cited as authority that such conduct constitutes an “indirect interference” under § 14.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “We must decide (1) whether a tenant must pay full rent without abatement when the landlord, acting without fault or bad faith, fails to maintain a dwelling in habitable condition and (2) whether the tenant’s obligation to pay full rent persists until the landlord has had a reasonable time to repair the defect. We hold that the tenant’s obligation abates as soon as the landlord has notice that premises fail to comply with the requirements of the warranty of habitability. The landlord’s lack of fault and reasonable efforts to repair do not prolong the duty to pay full rent.”
